III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
1

(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 put her hands on Youth A’s (daughter of Resident A)
neck/shoulders to stop the youth from running around. The youth
had resulting red marks on their neck and chest area.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face-to-face alongside MDHHS
Specialist on 6/18/25. Director reported the residents involved are
18 and older.
Resident A and Resident B were interviewed face-to-face along
with MDHHS Specialist. Resident A and Resident B are each
reported to be 18 or older.
Analysis The allegation received is in reference to a resident above the age
of 18 therefore there are no child welfare licensing concerns
applicable to this complaint.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4104
Section Rules compliance
Description (2) After being licensed, an institution shall, on an ongoing basis,
comply with the act, child caring institution rules, and terms of the
license.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility is accepting both adults and children into the program.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face-to-face alongside MDHHS
Specialist on 6/18/25. Director reported there are residents at the
facility who are 18 and older. Another interview of Director took
place at the facility on 8/19/25 with Area Manager and Consultant.
Director reported they work to keep the youth and adults separate
at the facility but they do share some common areas and special
events that take place within the facility. She reported the youth
have a separate dining schedule and have separate sleeping
areas. While the youth and adults share the common area and
entrances she did state this is something they can change to
ensure the populations are not mixing.
2

Resident A and Resident B were interviewed face-to-face along
with MDHHS Specialist. Resident A and Resident B are each 20
years old.
Consultant reported the facility services youth and adults at the
same building at the same physical address. Consultant reported
to her knowledge the adults and youth placed were separated for
sleeping and eating. Consultant did not provide any further
information.
Facility Tour:
A tour of the facility was conducted on 8/19/25 by Area Manager
and Consultant. The facility is located in a multi-purpose building
with the CCI located on the second floor. Once on the second
floor there are two doors that enter into the CCI. One door enters
into the kitchen. From the kitchen is a dining room. When exiting
the dining room is a hallway that is shaped like a horseshoe with
the opposite end leading to the other door leading to the CCI.
Across from the dining room are 2 locked doors that require a key
fob to enter. Upon entry to either door there are 3 inner doors 2
bedrooms and 1 to a bathroom that is shared with the other side.
When going right out of the dining room there is a common area
with a television, staff office, portable divider, games and art
supplies. This room has a door on both sides of the room. To the
left of the dining room and down the hallway the hallway ends at a
“T” with a stairwell to the right and to the left are doors to the adult
bedrooms. Pass the adult bedrooms is the other entrance to the
CCI.
Document Review:
• Alternatives for Girls Roster dated 6/16/2025 documents
the placement of 15 youth with 13 aged 18 or older and 2
under the age of 18. Intake dates for the adult placements
are after they turned 18 years of age.
• Email authored by Chief Administrator states “The
participants eating and sleeping areas are separated. The
minors (youth between 15-17 years of age) are in a locked
suite area that staff swiped them in to get to their rooms.
The adults without children are separated on a different
side of the building from the expecting and/or parenting
mothers with children. The minor participants are always
supervised by staff and usually attend activities separate
from the adults. On occasion when the agency has
received sports or event tickets, the two can attend
together with staff present.”
3

• Program Statement states the Stepping Stones Program
serves youth 15-17, the Emergency Shelter and the
Aftercare Services Program serves residents aged 15-21.
Analysis The facility is in violation of the licensing rule as it pertains to
compliance with PA 116 MCL 722.111. The facility is providing
services to youth under 18 years of age and adults 18 years of
age or older at the licensed CCI.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
